overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students identify key characteristics of linear functions. They use graphs to investigate <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></math>, <math><mi>A</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−<!-- − --></mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, and <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. Given a function <math><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in terms of <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, students graph <math><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> and describe each transformation on <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> to produce <math><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. Finally, students test a game that uses transformations of linear functions to hit targets.

overview_item_data_items: I can connect the domain of a function to the context it represents using quantities.
I can graph a linear function transformation expressed symbolically.

I can generalize the effects of replacing <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> by <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></math>, <math><mi>A</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−<!-- − --></mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, or <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> for a linear function.

The function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></math> is a vertical translation of the basic function <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>. When <math><mi>D</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the graph vertically shifts up, and when <math><mi>D</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the graph vertically shifts down. The amount of shift is given by <math><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow></math>.

The function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is a vertical dilation of the basic function <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>. When <math><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></math>, the graph stretches vertically by a factor of <math><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow></math>, and when <math><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, the graph compresses vertically by a factor of <math><mi>A</mi></math>. When <math><mi>A</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the graph reflects across the x-axis.

The function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−<!-- − --></mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is a horizontal translation of the basic function <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>. When <math><mi>C</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the graph horizontally shifts right, and when <math><mi>C</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the graph horizontally shifts left. The amount of shift is given by <math><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow></math>.

The function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is a horizontal dilation of the basic function <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>. When <math><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></math>, the graph compresses horizontally by a factor of <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfrac></math>. When <math><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, the graph stretches horizontally by a factor of <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfrac></math>. When <math><mi>B</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the graph reflects across the y-axis.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students graph translations and dilations of a given line segment.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Investigating Vertical Translations and Vertical Dilations
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students generalize that the <math><mi>D</mi></math>-value in the function transformation form, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></math>, vertically translates the graph, and that the <math><mi>A</mi></math>-value in the function transformation form, <math><mi>A</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, horizontally dilates the graph.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Vertical Translations and Vertical Dilations of Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students generalize that the <math><mi>A</mi></math>-value affects the slope of the function, while the <math><mi>D</mi></math>-value affects the y-intercept.
Students match graphs of transformations with their functions.
Go online for Session Launch recommendations.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_title: Horizontal Translations and Horizontal Dilations of Functions
overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students generalize that the <math><mi>C</mi></math>-value in the function transformation form, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−<!-- − --></mo><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, horizontally translates the graph, and that the <math><mi>B</mi></math>-value in the function transformation form, <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, horizontally dilates the graph.
Students write equations for transformed functions in the context of a problem situation.

Consider the graph of the linear function <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math> and four transformations of <math><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
